Posts.Content: Why not take something to take the edge off? You are going through a big ordeal. My knee surgeon OK'd a valium the morning of my surgery. My husband took a Valium the morning of his second biopsy and it helped, although he got "chatty". Don't take Xanax as there is a kick back after four hours or so, meaning you get more anxious when it wears off. (Husband is a doc.) And remember, it's just a normal work day for anesthesia, nurses, techs, and the doctors! Surgery is scary, but you will probably find that on the day of, you will be calm!
Posts.Signature: Husband, age 72: PSA: 2014: first ever in April 2014: 25.7, after Finasteride PSA was 7 and then 9 Biopsy in May 2014 negative High tech MRI at MassGeneral: 1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle. December 2014: MRI/ultrasound guided biopsy: Gleason 3-3, 7 cores positive out of 15 PNI present Bone scan clear Doctors now rank him as high-intermediate risk, if he chose surgery he would have had hormone and radiation therapy afterward. They give him a 75% chance of a cure. Surgeon thought his post op path report would have found a higher Gleason, due to high PSA. He chose radiation therapy. He has begun six months of hormone therapy and 8.5 weeks of radiation will start in April at MGH.

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: We were told two different things. One that you can't tell for sure if lymph nodes are impacted except by surgical removal and pathology. And that the 3T MRI shows if a lymph node is enlarged, and therefore suspect.

Posts.Title: Bone scan/MRI tomorrow - What's next?

Posts.Content: My husband had this done at MassGeneral last week. Not sure if it was a "named" procedure, or software. I wasn't in the room, but I know the doc did just this, superimposed the MRI images onto the real time ultrasound. He took fifteen samples, three were for a research study. (I assume they were doubles.) We had to wait six weeks for this specific test, as his regular urologist doesn't do it. Dr. Feldman did the test and my husband said he had excellent technique. My husband had fifteen negative samples in his biopsy earlier in the year with the endorectal ultrasound. Oh, and for future biopsy testing, my husband found that he was much more comfortable with 5 mg of Valium on board. He didn't want to take narcotics because of having to drink a ton of water afterward and urinate. He's a physician and said that narcotics can impact urination in a negative way. We are waiting for the results of this biopsy, none too patiently.

Posts.Title: Harvard Medical School 2015 Report on Prostate Disease

Posts.Content: Boy, you dodged a bullet! I'm glad you made the decision you did. It was the right thing to do in your case. This is an odd disease with so many variables. It's awfully difficult to decide a treatment course. Congrats.

Posts.Title: My experience

Posts.Content: I've tried to read all the papers you listed, because I hear your concerns. As you know there is no literature that randomly selects men, with similar disease criteria, and puts them in to a primary radiation treatment or primary surgical treatment. No man, that I know, would agree to that. Not on this site, anyway. I think it's worth looking at whether surgery to remove a high Gleason prostate is better than radiation and drug therapy alone. I've said a million times (I'm sorry to be boring about it) that we are lucky that our internist has studied prostate cancer his whole professional life. He told us that men with high PSAs do better with surgery. He had the data to back that up. And my high PSA husband still can not get his head around surgery and chose radiation. Despite the fact that husband has spent many years doing research as a physician, he did not follow the data, he followed his personal preference. I very much wanted him to do surgery, but I was afraid he would choose no treatment, and his cancer was too advanced for that choice. I've been supportive of his choice, but asked him the other day if he would reconsider and have surgery. "Ugh!" he replied. I guess not. He had his first hot flash this morning, it's almost three weeks since his Lupron injection and he takes Casodex.

They give him a 75% chance of a cure. Surgeon thought his post op path report would have found a higher Gleason, due to high PSA. He chose radiation therapy. He has begun six months of hormone therapy and 8.5 weeks of radiation will start in April at MGH.
Posts.Title: MD Anderson (multi site) Trial for late stage PC

Posts.Content: There is a lot of getting used to in "the new normal". For me, a wife, when my husband was first diagnosed I briefly lost interest in sex. This sounds really stupid, but I was angry at his body for getting cancer. I got over it, but we humans don't always make sense. Maybe your wife could go to the doctor with you and talk about it, or she could go to her own doctor. Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Husband now a Member of the Club

Posts.Content: We went for the "high tech" biopsy today. The younger urologist superimposed the MRI images onto the screen of the ultrasound. The computer crashed mid-biopsy, and had to be rebooted. He took fifteen samples, three for a study he's doing, and all went well. My husband took 5 mg of Valium before hand and was very comfortable. He thinks it helped enormously. He's busy drinking water and having soup. And now we wait. The biopsy reading will probably be delayed due to Christmas week, but hopefully we'll be busy enough not to worry, too much.
Posts.Signature: Husband, age 72: PSA: 2014: first ever in April 2014: 25.7, after Finasteride PSA was 7 and then 9 Biopsy in May 2014 negative High tech MRI at MassGeneral: 1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle. They give him a 75% chance of a cure. Surgeon thought his post op path report would have found a higher Gleason, due to high PSA. He chose radiation therapy. He has begun six months of hormone therapy and 8.5 weeks of radiation will start in April at MGH.
Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Husband is 72 and previously healthy. He's being treated at MassGeneral Hospital. He had his first PSA this summer and it was in the 20's. Had a biopsy, the urologist did 15 pokes, and all were benign. Three months later husband's PSA was 7. He recently had an MRI and his third PSA which was 9. His MRI result is that he has "1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle." Next step is a biopsy done by the young guys with fancy equipment. That will happen later in December. He will then will go before a committee for treatment recommendations. That's all we know at this point, and it obviously is not good. We aren't freaking out, but are not happy either. We'll do the best we can, and will even laugh along the way. What else are you going to do? Thanks for your help.

Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: OK, how about some questions: And, aghhhh, the waiting. His "fancy" biopsy, I assume guided by "something" will occur right before Christmas. My husband's first concern was that he should retire, because the cancer had moved out of the prostate, as indicated in the MRI. He is still working, and although he has to be mentally alert, he does his job sitting in a comfortable chair. He's calmed down a bit, but we'd like to know what the recovery period is like after a prostatectomy and/or radiation? Are there other treatments and recoveries that we should know about. I think just about all the males in his high school and college classes have had prostate problems, with a full variety of treatment modalities, and all good outcomes.
Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Sorry, Chuck, I didn't answer your question. I assume that the committee consists of doctors from different specialties. Husband's urologist calls it "The Politburo". Newporter, I'd say that ED is important! But I'd rather have the husband alive, and well, the rest is secondary. My impulse is to get that prostate outta here, but it's not my body. Shu246, thanks for sharing your experience. He needs to sit comfortably and talk to people. He does so now, for many hours a day. But you can't always do what you did before. We'll manage whatever comes along.

Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Bunnabrock, I am so sorry that you two have had to face this tough diagnosis at such a young age. I'm glad you found a hospital where you got good care. I'm new to this, my husband just started hormone therapy this week. I am learning about blood levels. Are they going to give him spot radiation for the tumors on his bones? Take care and keep us informed.

I'm new to this, my husband just started hormone therapy this week. I am learning about blood levels. Are they going to give him spot radiation for the tumors on his bones? Take care and keep us informed.
Posts.Signature: Husband, age 72: PSA: 2014: first ever in April 2014: 25.7, after Finasteride PSA was 7 and then 9 Biopsy in May 2014 negative High tech MRI at MassGeneral: 1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle. December 2014: MRI/ultrasound guided biopsy: Gleason 3-3, 7 cores positive out of 15 PNI present Bone scan clear Doctors now rank him as high-intermediate risk, if he chose surgery he would have had hormone and radiation therapy afterward. They give him a 75% chance of a cure. Surgeon thought his post op path report would have found a higher Gleason, due to high PSA. He chose radiation therapy. He has begun six months of hormone therapy and 8.5 weeks of radiation will start in April at MGH.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed metastatic prostate cancer--PSA and testosterone levels

Posts.Content: Husband is 72 and previously healthy. He's being treated at MassGeneral Hospital. He had his first PSA this summer and it was in the 20's. Had a biopsy, the urologist did 15 pokes, and all were benign. Three months later husband's PSA was 7. He recently had an MRI and his third PSA which was 9. His MRI result is that he has "1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle." Next step is a biopsy done by the young guys with fancy equipment. That will happen later in December. He will then will go before a committee for treatment recommendations. That's all we know at this point, and it obviously is not good. We aren't freaking out, but are not happy either. We'll do the best we can, and will even laugh along the way. What else are you going to do? Thanks for your help.
Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: We went for the "high tech" biopsy today. The younger urologist superimposed the MRI images onto the screen of the ultrasound. The computer crashed mid-biopsy, and had to be rebooted. He took fifteen samples, three for a study he's doing, and all went well. My husband took 5 mg of Valium before hand and was very comfortable. He thinks it helped enormously. He's busy drinking water and having soup. And now we wait. The biopsy reading will probably be delayed due to Christmas week, but hopefully we'll be busy enough not to worry, too much.

He has begun six months of hormone therapy and 8.5 weeks of radiation will start in April at MGH.

Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: OK, how about some questions: And, aghhhh, the waiting. His "fancy" biopsy, I assume guided by "something" will occur right before Christmas. My husband's first concern was that he should retire, because the cancer had moved out of the prostate, as indicated in the MRI. He is still working, and although he has to be mentally alert, he does his job sitting in a comfortable chair. He's calmed down a bit, but we'd like to know what the recovery period is like after a prostatectomy and/or radiation? Are there other treatments and recoveries that we should know about. I think just about all the males in his high school and college classes have had prostate problems, with a full variety of treatment modalities, and all good outcomes.

Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Sorry, Chuck, I didn't answer your question. I assume that the committee consists of doctors from different specialties. Husband's urologist calls it "The Politburo". Newporter, I'd say that ED is important! But I'd rather have the husband alive, and well, the rest is secondary. My impulse is to get that prostate outta here, but it's not my body. Shu246, thanks for sharing your experience. He needs to sit comfortably and talk to people. He does so now, for many hours a day. But you can't always do what you did before. We'll manage whatever comes along.

Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Thank you for starting this thread. My husband is following in your footsteps. He's been on hormone therapy, Lupron and Casodex, for two weeks. He begins radiation at the end of April. I don't see a lot of day to day information on radiation therapy, and I'll be following your posts carefully. I hope you do terrifically well! Chili
